writing_prompt: A master art forger turned FBI consultant finds himself at a crossroads when his old partner proposes a heist that feels... wrong. For the first time, he hesitates—has he really changed, or is he just fooling himself?
story:
He really didn't think he's changing in any way, shape or form. Not when it came down to it. Neal Caffrey, the master art forger, the con artist, the thief - that was who he was. And yet, as he stood in the dimly lit alley, listening to Mozzie's proposal, he felt a nagging sense of unease.

"It's a simple in-and-out job, Neal," Mozzie said, his eyes gleaming with excitement. "We get in, we swap the painting, and we're out. Easy money."

But it wasn't the ease of the job that bothered Neal. It was the why. The painting in question was a priceless artifact, one that belonged to a small museum in the city. The owner, a kind old man, had poured his heart and soul into collecting and preserving these pieces of history. And Mozzie wanted to steal it from him.

Neal shifted uncomfortably, his mind racing with thoughts. He had always told himself that he was a thief, not a monster. He stole from the rich, from those who could afford it. But this... this felt different.

"What's wrong, Neal?" Mozzie asked, noticing his hesitation. "You're not getting cold feet, are you?"

Neal shook his head, trying to clear the cobwebs. "No, no, it's just... I don't know, Mozzie. This feels off."

Mozzie snorted. "Off? It's a heist, Neal. It's what we do."

But Neal couldn't shake off the feeling. He thought back to his time with the FBI, working with Peter and the team. They had changed him, or at least, he thought they had. He had started to see the world in a different light, to question his own morality.

Or had he just been fooling himself?

As he walked away from Mozzie, Neal couldn't help but wonder if he was still the same old Neal, or if he had truly changed. He thought about the people he had met, the cases he had worked on, the lives he had touched.

He thought about Peter, and the way he had looked at him, like he was more than just a con artist. Like he was a person worth saving.

Neal sighed, running a hand through his hair. He didn't know what to do. Part of him wanted to go back to Mozzie, to take the easy money and forget about the doubts. But another part of him, a part he was starting to realize was growing louder, wanted to walk away.

To walk away from the heist, from Mozzie, from the life he had always known.

As he walked through the city streets, Neal felt lost. He didn't know who he was anymore, or what he wanted. He only knew that he couldn't shake off the feeling that he was standing at a crossroads, with no clear direction in sight.

He stopped in front of a small café, hesitating for a moment before pushing open the door. Inside, he spotted Peter, sipping on a cup of coffee.

"Neal," Peter said, looking up. "What brings you here?"

Neal slid into the booth across from him, unsure of what to say. "Just needed some coffee, I guess."

Peter raised an eyebrow. "You look like you've lost your last friend."

Neal laughed, a dry, humorless sound. "Maybe I have."

Peter leaned forward, his eyes serious. "You know, Neal, I've always thought that you were more than just a con artist. That there was something good in you, something worth saving."

Neal looked away, feeling a pang in his chest. "You've been wrong about me, Peter. I'm just a thief."

But Peter's words lingered in his mind, echoing the doubts he had been having. Was he still the same old Neal, or was he something more? Only time would tell.

writing_prompt: When Crowley ran into Dean Winchester after years apart, he never expected it to lead to late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and a life tangled with federal agents and family barbecues. But some things, it seems, are worth rewriting the plan for.
story:
It had been years since Crowley last laid eyes on Dean Winchester, and yet, the man still had the uncanny ability to make him feel like he was the only person in the room. They collided, quite literally, on a bustling street corner in downtown Chicago, and for a moment, time seemed to stand still.

Crowley's initial instinct was to brush past Dean, to pretend that their encounter was nothing more than a mere coincidence. But as their eyes met, he saw something there that gave him pause. A flicker of recognition, a spark of curiosity, and a dash of wariness. It was enough to make Crowley's curiosity get the better of him.

"Dean Winchester," he drawled, his voice low and smooth. "It's been a while."

Dean's eyes narrowed, his gaze piercing as he took in Crowley's tailored suit and immaculate grooming. "Crowley. I might have known you'd turn up like a bad penny."

The tension between them was palpable, a living, breathing thing that seemed to pulse with a life of its own. Crowley felt it, a thrumming in his veins that he couldn't quite ignore. He smiled, a slow, lazy smile that seemed to draw Dean in despite himself.

"I see you're still as charming as ever," Dean said, his voice dripping with sarcasm, but Crowley detected a hint of warmth beneath the surface.

As they stood there, the world around them melted away, leaving only the two of them, suspended in a sea of what-ifs and maybes. Crowley felt the weight of their history bearing down on him, the memories of their complicated past threatening to overwhelm him. But he pushed them aside, focusing instead on the present, on the spark that still seemed to simmer between them.

"Would you like to grab a drink with me, Dean?" he asked, the words spilling out of him before he could think better of it.

Dean raised an eyebrow, his expression skeptical, but Crowley could see the faintest glimmer of interest in his eyes. "What's the catch, Crowley?"

Crowley shrugged, a careless gesture that belied the turmoil brewing inside him. "No catch, Dean. Just a drink. And maybe, just maybe, a chance to catch up on old times."

The hours that followed were a blur of whiskey-soaked conversation and stolen glances, the tension between them building to a crescendo that left Crowley breathless. They talked about nothing and everything, their words spilling out in a torrent of laughter and memories.

It was late, the night wearing thin, when Crowley finally walked Dean back to his hotel room. The air was heavy with anticipation, the silence between them thick with unspoken promises. Crowley felt his heart pounding in his chest as Dean turned to him, his eyes burning with a fire that seemed to consume them both.

"Thanks for the drink, Crowley," Dean said, his voice low and husky, the words hanging in the air like a challenge.

Crowley's smile was a slow, seductive thing, his eyes never leaving Dean's as he reached out to brush a strand of hair from his forehead. The touch sent shivers down his spine, the spark between them igniting into a flame that seemed to consume them both.

As the days turned into weeks, Crowley found himself drawn into Dean's world, a world of federal agents and family barbecues, of laughter and tears and late-night confessions. It was a world he never could have anticipated, one that was messy and complicated and utterly, completely his.

And as he stood beside Dean, watching the sun set over the horizon, Crowley knew that he would never be the same again. Some things, it seemed, were worth rewriting the plan for.

writing_prompt: A con artist turned FBI consultant accidentally finds himself defending proper legal procedures during a heated case discussion—much to the amusement of his by-the-book handler, who never lets him live it down.
story:
Neal Caffrey adjusted his tie for what felt like the hundredth time that morning, smoothing out the wrinkles as he strolled into the conference room. The team was already seated, surrounded by stacks of files and empty coffee cups. Peter, ever the punctual one, raised an eyebrow at Neal's tardiness.

"Sorry, sorry," Neal said, flashing a charming smile as he took his seat. "Traffic."

Peter raised an eyebrow. "You took a detour via the fashion district, didn't you?"

Neal chuckled, unfazed. "Maybe I just wanted to make a good impression."

The team leader, Diana, cleared her throat, bringing the meeting to order. The discussion centered around their current case, a complex web of embezzlement and money laundering that had Neal's expertise in high demand. As the team debated the best course of action, Neal found himself growing increasingly agitated.

"Come on, guys, we can't just barge in there without a warrant," he said, his voice rising. "We need to follow procedure."

Peter's eyes lit up with amusement, and he leaned back in his chair, steepling his fingers together. "Neal Caffrey, defending the sanctity of the law. Who would have thought?"

Neal shot him a withering look. "Hey, I'm just saying, we can't afford to mess this up. We need to build a solid case."

Jones, the junior agent, looked at him in surprise. "I didn't know you were such a stickler for the rules, Neal."

Neal shrugged. "Hey, someone's got to keep you guys honest. And besides, I've had my fair share of experience with... creative interpretations of the law."

Peter chuckled. "That's one way to put it."

As the meeting continued, Neal found himself growing more and more passionate about the importance of following procedure. It wasn't until they were wrapping up that he realized Peter was still grinning at him.

"What?" Neal asked, feeling a little self-conscious.

Peter shook his head. "I just never thought I'd see the day where you'd be the one lecturing us on the importance of doing things by the book."

Neal rolled his eyes. "Hey, I'm a changed man."

Peter snorted. "Yeah, right. And I'm the Queen of England."

Neal laughed, feeling a little silly. "Okay, okay, maybe I'm not entirely reformed. But I'm trying, Peter. I really am."

Peter's expression softened, and he clapped Neal on the back. "I know you are, Neal. And I appreciate it. Even if it is a little funny to see you playing the role of law-and-order advocate."

As they left the conference room, Neal muttered under his breath, "I'm going to make sure to bill you for this one, Peter."

Peter just chuckled and said, "I'm shaking in my boots, Neal."

The rest of the day was a blur of paperwork and witness interviews, but Neal couldn't shake the feeling that he'd somehow turned a corner. He was still a con artist at heart, but maybe, just maybe, he was starting to find a new role for himself within the FBI. One that didn't involve quite so much... creative license.

As he packed up his things to leave, Peter caught his eye and said, "You know, Neal, I think you might just make a decent agent yet."

Neal raised an eyebrow. "Don't get too excited, Peter. I still have a few tricks up my sleeve."

Peter just smiled. "I'm counting on it."

writing_prompt: The starship is stranded, dead in space, with no apparent reason for the failure. As the clock ticks down and theories crumble, the chief engineer must uncover the truth before the crew's time runs out.
story:
He had been through many a storm already with different ships, how difficult could it be? Montgomery Scott, chief engineer of the USS Enterprise, was not one to panic easily. The ship was his domain, and he knew her better than he knew his own wife. But as he gazed out at the viewscreen, his confidence began to waver. The stars twinkled like diamonds against the blackness, but the Enterprise was dead in the water – dead in space.

"What's the situation, Mr. Scott?" Captain Kirk's voice was calm, but Montgomery could sense the undercurrent of concern.

"It's as if she just... stopped, sir," Montgomery replied, running a hand through his thinning hair. "I've checked the warp core, the impulse engines, everything. There's no reason for this."

Mr. Spock, as could be expected for any good science officer, had a few theories, but nothing concrete as yet. "It's possible that we've encountered an unknown energy field, Captain," he suggested, his eyes fixed on the data streaming across his console.

Montgomery snorted. "I've seen some weird things in my time, but this? It's like the ship just decided to take a wee nap."

The captain's eyes narrowed. "Let's not rule out anything just yet, Mr. Scott. Keep working on it. We need a solution, and fast."

As the hours ticked by, Montgomery's team worked tirelessly to diagnose the problem. Theories were proposed and discarded, but the ship remained stubbornly still. It was young Chekov who gave Montgomery the idea. "You know, sir, in Russia, we used to do something called schemitsa."

Montgomery raised an eyebrow. "Bear hunting. It was... a trap."

Chekov nodded enthusiastically. "Da, sir! We would use a small, weak animal to lure the bear into a trap. Maybe, sir, this... this energy field, it's like the small animal. We just need to find the trap."

Montgomery's eyes lit up. "That's it, laddie! The ship's not just dead in space, she's being held in place. There's something out there, something that's not showing up on our sensors."

With renewed hope, Montgomery set to work. He called up the ship's internal sensors, searching for any sign of the mysterious energy field. It was a long shot, but it was worth a try.

As the minutes ticked by, the tension on the bridge grew. The crew's banter, usually a staple of their interactions, was replaced by worried glances and hushed whispers. Montgomery's team worked in silence, their faces set in determined lines.

And then, just as Montgomery was about to give up hope, the sensors beeped. "I've got something, Captain!" he exclaimed, his Scottish brogue thick with excitement.

Kirk's eyes snapped to the viewscreen. "What is it, Mr. Scott?"

"It's a... a network of energy filaments, sir. They're holding us in place."

Spock's eyes narrowed. "Fascinating. It would appear that we have stumbled into an ancient trap, Captain."

Montgomery let out a whoop of triumph. "I knew it, laddies! The ship's not broken, she's just... stuck."

With the solution in hand, the crew set to work, carefully navigating the energy filaments and freeing the Enterprise from her invisible prison. As the ship shuddered back to life, Montgomery felt a sense of pride and relief wash over him.

The instructors in the academy had always told him he should stay professional, that no captain worth a damn would call him by a nickname. But Captain Kirk had proven them wrong right from the start. "Well done, Scotty," he said, with a grin. "You've done it again."

Montgomery smiled, feeling the tension dissipate. "Aye, Captain. She's a beautiful lady, alright. There's a reason she's the flagship of the Federation."

writing_prompt: When a relentless agent arrives to audit Peter's team, Neal finds himself under suspicion for a forgery he didn’t commit. To clear his name—and protect Peter—he hatches a plan that might just blur the line between clever and reckless.
story:
Neal Caffrey sat in his favorite armchair, sipping his morning coffee and staring out the window at the Manhattan skyline. It was moments like these that he cherished, the quiet before the storm, when he could collect his thoughts and reflect on his life. He had come a long way since his con artist days, and his partnership with FBI Agent Peter Burke had been a game-changer. Peter had seen something in him that no one else had - potential. And Neal had to admit, he had grown quite fond of the straight-laced agent and his team.

But as he delved deeper into his thoughts, Neal's mind began to wander to the past. He had always been a master of deception, a chameleon who could blend into any situation. Yet, with Peter, he had found a sense of belonging, of being part of something bigger than himself. The question was, had he truly changed, or was he just playing a new role?

Just as Neal was lost in his musings, his phone buzzed, breaking the silence. He glanced at the screen and groaned inwardly. It was Peter, and he sounded serious.

"Neal, we have a problem. An auditor is coming in today to review our cases, and I need you to be on your best behavior."

Neal's instincts kicked in, and he felt a twinge of unease. What did this auditor want? And why did Peter sound so apprehensive?

As the day unfolded, Neal's anxiety grew. The auditor, a no-nonsense woman named Agent Thompson, was relentless in her questioning. She seemed to be gunning for him, and Neal couldn't shake the feeling that she was looking for something specific.

It wasn't until she dropped the bombshell that Neal's world began to spin. "We've received a tip that a forgery was committed on one of your cases, Caffrey. Care to explain?"

Neal's mind racing, he knew he had to think fast. He hadn't committed any forgery, but he had a feeling he was being set up. And if he didn't clear his name, Peter's reputation would be on the line.

"I don't know what you're talking about," Neal said, trying to sound calm.

Agent Thompson raised an eyebrow. "Don't play dumb, Caffrey. We have evidence."

Neal's eyes met Peter's, and he saw a flicker of doubt. For a moment, he felt like he was back in his old life, where trust was a luxury he couldn't afford.

But then, something clicked. He remembered the countless times Peter had stood by him, the trust they had built over the years. Neal knew he had to protect Peter, no matter what.

"I need to make a phone call," Neal said, his mind already racing with a plan.

As he stepped out of the room, Neal's thoughts turned to his past, to the skills he had honed as a con artist. He knew he was taking a risk, but he was willing to blur the line between clever and reckless if it meant clearing his name and protecting Peter.

The plan began to take shape in his mind, a complex web of misdirection and deception. Neal's heart pounded with excitement as he dialed a number, his eyes locked on the door, waiting for the perfect moment to strike.

This was it - his chance to prove his loyalty, to show Peter that he was more than just a con artist. Neal took a deep breath, the thrill of the game coursing through his veins.

It was time to put on a show.
